Menu

A diagnosis of XLH is typically based on clinical and biochemical findings in combination with family history

Consider a patient's family history

Family history can help determine whether a patient has XLH.

WITH KNOWN FAMILY HISTORY OF XLH

In a family with a history of XLH, screen for other family members. This can help you identify previously undiagnosed individuals.

WITHOUT A KNOWN FAMILY HISTORY OF XLH

About 20% to 30% of XLH cases are spontaneous.6 Ask about his/her medical history of short stature, rickets, osteomalacia, osteoarthritis, and dental abscesses, which may indicate XLH.

Assess clinical findings

The following are predominant clinical findings in children and adults.

Children

Rickets, lower extremity bowing, leg deformities, and decreased height velocity become apparent in growing children.1,2

Adults

Adults with XLH may present with osteomalacia, short stature, dental abscesses, and bone and muscle pain.3-5 Enthesopathy, osteoarthritis, fractures, pseudofractures, and hearing loss may also manifest in older adults.3-5

Confirm family history and clinical findings with biochemical tests

Biochemical assessments help support the diagnosis of XLH and prevent misdiagnosis. It is important to include age- and gender-normalized levels of serum phosphorus in metabolic panels. Low phosphate levels, low TmP/GFR ratio, and low-to-normal circulating 1,25(OH)2D are the most relevant biochemical findings for XLH.1, 2

Key biochemicals findings for xhl

“The specific tests that puts us in the realm of XLH are serum phosphorus levels and in particular, urinary phosphate excretion.”

—Dr. Thomas Carpenter, XLH expert

Currently, there are no FDA-approved therapies to treat XLH.

Understanding the strategies to symptom management in children and adults with XLH can help you provide better care for patients.

Understand how to diagnose XLH
